segment.source: Describes the best practices, location, values, management aspects, and security considerations for the Network security: Restrict NTLM: Add server exceptions in this domain security policy setting.
segment.target: Describes the best practices, location, values, management aspects, and security considerations for the Network security: Restrict NTLM: Add server exceptions in this domain security policy setting.

segment.source: The Network security: Restrict NTLM: Add server exceptions in this domain policy setting allows you to create an exception list of servers in this domain to which client device are allowed to use NTLM pass-through authentication if any of the deny options are set in the Network Security: Restrict NTLM: NTLM authentication in this domain policy setting.
segment.target: The Network security: Restrict NTLM: Add server exceptions in this domain policy setting allows you to create an exception list of servers in this domain to which client device are allowed to use NTLM pass-through authentication if any of the deny options are set in the Network Security: Restrict NTLM: NTLM authentication in this domain policy setting.

segment.source: If you configure this policy setting, you can define a list of servers in this domain to which client devices are allowed to use NTLM authentication.
segment.target: If you configure this policy setting, you can define a list of servers in this domain to which client devices are allowed to use NTLM authentication.

segment.source: If you do not configure this policy setting, no exceptions will be applied, and if Network Security: Restrict NTLM: NTLM authentication in this domain is enabled, all NTLM authentication attempts in the domain will fail.
segment.target: If you do not configure this policy setting, no exceptions will be applied, and if Network Security: Restrict NTLM: NTLM authentication in this domain is enabled, all NTLM authentication attempts in the domain will fail.

segment.source: When you enter a list of servers in this domain to which clients are allowed to use NTLM authentication, the policy is defined and enabled.

segment.source: If you do not configure this policy setting by defining a list of servers, the policy is undefined and no exceptions will be applied.

segment.source: First enforce the Network Security: Restrict NTLM: Audit NTLM authentication in this domain policy setting, and then review the operational event log to understand what domain controllers are involved in these authentication attempts so you can decide which servers to exempt.

segment.source: When it has been determined that the NTLM authentication protocol should not be used within a domain because you are required to use a more secure protocol such as Kerberos, there might be some NTLM authentication traffic that is still present in the domain.
segment.target: When it has been determined that the NTLM authentication protocol should not be used within a domain because you are required to use a more secure protocol such as Kerberos, there might be some NTLM authentication traffic that is still present in the domain.

segment.source: If so, and you set Network Security: Network Security: Restrict NTLM: NTLM authentication in this domain to any of the deny options, any NTLM authentication request will fail because the pass-through member server will block the NTLM request.
segment.target: If so, and you set Network Security: Network Security: Restrict NTLM: NTLM authentication in this domain to any of the deny options, any NTLM authentication request will fail because the pass-through member server will block the NTLM request.

segment.source: If you define an exception list of servers in this domain to which client computers are allowed to use NTLM pass-through authentication, then NTLM authentication traffic will continue to flow between those servers, which make them vulnerable to any malicious attack that takes advantage of security weaknesses in NTLM.
segment.target: If you define an exception list of servers in this domain to which client computers are allowed to use NTLM pass-through authentication, then NTLM authentication traffic will continue to flow between those servers, which make them vulnerable to any malicious attack that takes advantage of security weaknesses in NTLM.

segment.source: When you use Network Security: Restrict NTLM: NTLM authentication in this domain in audit-only mode, you can determine by reviewing which client applications are making NTLM authentication requests to the pass-through authentication servers.
segment.target: When you use Network Security: Restrict NTLM: NTLM authentication in this domain in audit-only mode, you can determine by reviewing which client applications are making NTLM authentication requests to the pass-through authentication servers.
